description:
Onigilly was a lunch-time staple when I worked nearby. I love that there are so many options to mix and match depending on your mood. Feeling hungry? Order 3. Want a snack? Just get 1.

I was always drawn to the snow crab but after trying many times, I've realized that my favorites are the spicy shrimp and spicy bacon. Spice makes everything better.

This Onigilly is definitely a take-out spot. There's no seating and not even space for you to wait for your order inside. What you get is a compact and easy to eat lunch that you can even consume while you're walking.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Greedy little workers. 
This place is overrated and was average so so OK.. bad not very good service.  I ordered about $10 worth of food. I tipped them very generous $4 dollars. Wasn't able to can finish my meal so I asked for a back to Carrie because I have a few other things that end up two large for two hands the girl just said that she wants $.10 for it. 
 I nicely said take that from my tip please not that much big deal and the girl will not n refuse to do that so yes I wish o could've take. back my tip if I could and never go to them again but of course I'm traveling and visiting so that won't b  back ever either just giving you heads up to you $.10 for a tip
was at the way when I gave them 40% 
I regretted doing that.
author: Katherine A.

description:
I was so happy to find a place that serves onigiri--especially the ume filled kind. This kind of snack-meal is more common and everyday to the Japanese than even sushi.  Of course, there are quite a number of other fillings to be had, but it's the ume filling that took me back to my childhood.  My mom use to make these ahead of road trips my dad used to love taking the family out on.  

So, finally, The Bay Area gets to have something that is more authentically everyday Japanese food than even sushi or even probably ramen.  Count yourselves lucky Onigilly is here.
author: David E.

description: They have updated a little now and I think they added choices and made the menu a little easier to work with. I realized now that my previous review was a little harsh, after all, this is one of my goto places for lunch when I'm in town - it's always quick and always tasty. The rice bowl is a nice size and you can always get a "side" of a single Onigilly (I think that's what they're called). Prices here are San Francisco prices, I got used to this already so I'm comparing to other places in the city and I think this place is decently priced. Coming to town from Denver, I wish we had more healthy choices like this - fresh and tasty. I recommend.
author: Gil S.

description: Omg. These are so good! I got the edamame set. Got unagi, salmon, and snow crab onigris. The rice was so soft and warm. The snow crab was amazing!!! Definitely get that. All of them were extremely flavorful.
author: Rose F.

description: I ordered the rice bowl and it comes with half salad and half rice with the choice of three sides. The rice side was good but it's like three tiny scoops. didn't really like the mixed greens because the dressing is too vinegary. Overall, it taste pretty well balanced. And there's no seating inside or outside but if u walk a block over, there's a nice place with a fountain
author: Irene Z.

description: Cheap and delicious! I'd recommend coming here whenever you want a quick snack or lunch. It's well seasoned and has the perfect amount of filling. I'd definitely come back.
author: Aileen J.

description:
Got the Edamame set with Snow Crab, Spicy Miso Beef and Spicy Bacon. I enjoyed all three!

The snow crab was slightly sweet. I took a bite, realized how delicious it was, and set it down to save it for last

The spicy miso was good. Not too spicy and very seasoned...could be a tad on the salty side to some but I loved it 

The spicy bacon was, well it's bacon. I love bacon so anything bacon is delicious to me. Grease from this one ran down my hands too 

I easily devoured all 3. Consider this meal a pregame for Hawaii
author: Kat D.

description:
I tried their rice bowl with 3 filling options:

- salmon (would get again)
- soboro (beef - my fave! would definitely get again)
- teriyaki tofu (would not get again)

It's sort of weird how the edamame's in the bowl but not peeled.

Matcha green tea lemonade is really good, too.

$15 total, which is about average for this part of SF. Glad I tried it. Will probably stick to the actual onigiri next time.
author: Aivy C.

description:
If you're looking for a cheap, quick, healthy, and filling lunch, don't miss Onigilly. Like, literally. It's tucked away around the corner from where the address points you on a map, so keep your eyes peeled. 

Our group made a line out the door upon arrival, but we moved through quickly. I opted for edamame set that comes with your choice of three onigilly. The spicy bacon caught my eye, but ultimately I kept it a little less rich with two chicken teriyaki and one miso nasu (eggplant with miso and sesame). 

First, the edamame set is a ton of food. For 9ish bucks I easily could have enjoyed two meals from the amount of food I received. The edamame was tender and lightly salted. I wasn't a huge fan of my miso nasu onigilly - it wasn't bad by any means, but a little too sweet for taste. I did really dig the teriyaki, though. I was also a fan of the proportions with the bulk being rice and the fillings as an accent for flavor. Due to the ratio you fill up quick; I could barely finish my second piece. I wish I would have known about them when I lived near this neighborhood and was broke as a joke - it would have been a great a la carte treat!
author: Stacey L.

description:
Was searching for a vegan/vegetarian friendly joint to take a group, and tracked this place down on the suggestion of the brilliant Candice G. There was a bit of a goose chase in actually finding it (the address leads you to an office complex, but the restaurant is actually around the corner). It's tiny so it's easy to miss for sure - just barely enough space to stand in line and place your order. 

There are a ton of amazing onigiri options to choose from, whether you are a carnivore, pescatarian, or veggie lover. I went with a set that came with miso soup and really enjoyed both the crab and the tuna onigiri. The rice was warm and fresh and it was really impressive how quickly the kitchen staff worked to get all of our orders. They got one person's order wrong out of eight. 

It's also really affordable considering the location. The set of two onigiri and miso soup is $7.25 to $8.63 depending on the type of fillings, and it was definitely satisfying and filling. 

A really great choice if you're craving Japanese, short on time, and want a good value. I hope these guys stick around for a while!
author: Christina P.

description: Get a single, double, or a set of three - this place will satisfy your onigiri cravings! Customize each onigiri - Each filling option differs in price points, ranging up to $3.75. My favorites are the unagi, salmon, and snow crab. A great (and surprisingly filling!) lunch if you get the set of three, which comes with edamame and pickled plum. Delish!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Love the concept! Flavors can be improved a little. Onigilly is conveniently located right across the street from where I work so I decided to give it a try. I ordered the miso soup tray which included to onigiri and one cup of miso soup.

For my two onigiri I chose the spicy shrimp and spicy bacon. The spicy shrimp one was just a little bit bland. I was expecting it to have some more kick to it. Perhaps if it had a little bit more spice and some green onions to it, it would be better. The spicy bacon on the other hand was VERY flavorful. Definitely my favorite of the two. Nonetheless, the food was pretty good but I wasn't wowed with the options I chose. I will have to come back and try some of the other filling options. 

I came in around peak lunch time right around 12:30pm on the weekday and the line surprisingly wasn't too bad! My food came out quickly and was nice and fresh (you can actually see them making the onigiri from the window). 

Be advised - there isn't really a seating area here, but there is an open seating area right next to the salesforce building where you can pull up a chair and enjoy the food (weather permitting). 

Overall, pretty decent lunch option. Not wow worth but good for a quick lunch bite that isn't overly filling. I will be back to explore the other options.
author: Haley T.

description:
Came with co-workers for lunch around noon and there was a bit of a line, but nothing too crazy. I ordered the edamame set with Ume (pickled plum), snow crab, and unagi (eel). 

I really liked the snow crab and eel because it had fresh seafood taste. The ume was too sour and acidic for my taste, but it did pair well with the sushi rice. Definitely treat yourself to the seafood Onigilly!
author: Nathan C.

description:
We have a serious onigiri shortage in Minneapolis; it's straight F'ed. So I planned on soothing my cravings at Onigilly in SF, where I saw they have a variety of affordable, fast, and quality onigiri and Japanese snack options. 

This location is a grab-and-go spot, which was perfect to snag during a lunch break in the financial district. I highly suggest getting a "set", where you choose 3 types of onigiri and a side dish. I chose the edamame set because I'm a health buff (jk), plus added an order of tamagoyaki (sweet omelette). For my onigiri fillings I ordered: ume (pickled plum & shiso), soboro (ginger-honey beef), and snow crab (with lemon aioli). 

The rice was well-seasoned and cooked and was mouthwatering in the toasted seaweed/nori - some of my fave flavors ever. My favorite I like the ume and snow crab best. The ume may be an acquired taste though, as it's super sour and will make your face pucker but then you'll crave it hardcore and learn to love it. The snow crab was slightly sweet and paired well with the nuttiness of the nori. I sprinkled some of the hot pepper seasoning that you can grab at the counter.

TL;DR I give Onigilly five stars because it was flawless for quick and tasty takeout! I wish I could have tried all 17 of their onigiri fillings.
author: Kara D.

description:
I work nearby but I literally never leave the office to buy lunch so I'm pretty clueless when it comes to the area's offerings but I do know that from what I've had from other places in this area in the past, I don't really enjoy them. 

I ventured out to Onigilly for a group lunch today without realizing that it's a tiny space meant for take-out only. The menu, upon your first visit, takes a minute to figure out and could probably be organized a bit better but once you get it the sailing is smooth. 

Our group of 8-ish people got in, ordered, and out with all our stuff in like under 8 minutes, and we surprisingly only had one wrong order. 

I got the miso set with two onigilly (spicy shrimp & snow crab -both incredible). I was actually pretty shocked at how low their prices are, how good the food was, and how fast they could put everything together. It was the impossible trifecta, and they pulled it off.

Next time I'll probably get the same set but maybe add in a third onigilly because I'm a hungry b*tch.
author: Candice G.

description:
They only thing holding me back from 5 stars is that I didn't get what I ordered. Good news is that I really enjoyed what I got to eat! 

This small spot tucked away in the streets of San Francisco creates bowls and seaweed wrapped treats that almost satisfy my musubi cravings. Almost. Now, I'm not saying they are the same. I'm simply saying they are delicious. 

I feel it would be unfair for me to fully review what I ate because, to be honest, I'm not entirely sure. I do know that I devoured the bacon onigilly in all its salty and spicy glory. 

I loved this spot, even with the error, and will seek it out again. But after I get through the line, I'll be sure to make sure the order I receive is mine.
author: Taylor S.

description:
Decided to get the three self-identified spicy items on the menu.  All packed with flavor, though the spiciness level wasn't that spicy.  As always, love the crisp seaweed wrap around the tender sticky rice patties.

Spicy Miso Beef: Small granules of ground beef encased a thick miso gravy.  Almost like a Sloppy Joe version of a rice ball.  Tasty enough.

Wasabi Tuna Salad: Like canned tuna, not sushi tuna.  Better than a regular tuna fish sandwich; the wasabi added a nice kick.  Not as good as raw spicy tuna though.

Spicy Bacon: Still my favorite, because bacon!  Nice spicy-ish sauce to give it a little moisture.
author: Adam B.

description: I ordered the miso soup set which contains two choices of onigiri, I went with spicy shrimp and soboro which is ginger angus beef. My boyfriend got snow crab one. We both really like the ginger angus beef, it has great flavor and it is very special. However, I do find the look of the onigiri kinda disappointing, maybe I'm just asking too much by wanting a 2.5 dollar item to look good, but it just looks sloppy. Also, I find the spicy shrimp kinda boring, I asked them for their seven flavor spice, and sprinkled some on top, it is even spicier but less boring.
author: Shuang W.

description: Loved. Very creative, very great food, not over the top on price. I got the two with  seaweed salad and it was really good. I didn't LOVE the seaweed salad but it was pretty good. The actually rice balls themselves were the star of the show
author: Olivia G.

description:
I LOVE onigiri and living in the Midwest, it's hard to find. 
I appreciate the concept of a takeout place for something as simple and delicious as onigiris (Japanese rice balls). It's cheap and relatively quick, simple meal. 
It wasn't the best onigiris I've had but it was decent and for what it was, a quick to-go place, I'd say it hit the spot! 
You can order them individually or do a set of 3, which comes with: 3 rice balls, Takowan (pickled daikon/radish - this is super yums), and edamame.
You chose the filling of each rice ball, I got the umeboshi (pickled plum), miso tofu, and spicy shrimp. All were good, but I wasn't a fan of the spicy shrimp. The shrimps were really tiny and tasted like the dried shrimp you put in Japanese soup with some spicy mayo sauce mixed into it...it also had a funny after taste to it. However! The ume and tofu filled ones were both good! 

Can I get one out here, please?
author: Allena I.

description: Ok food but nothing special. The 3 masubi combo isn't very filling, pricey but good snack.
author: T L.

description: What a find, tucked over here in the shadow of Salesforce Tower. Great selection, meats, veggies, fish, all so tasty and easy on the budget. Perfect for grab & go. Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
I love the concept, but unfortunately I didn't feel the same way about actually eating here. 

Full disclosure, I did order an unagi salad which is something you probably want to eat inside room temperature if not somewhere the AC is cranked up. Instead, our group opted to take our lunch to an outdoor patio with the sun beaming down on both me and my eel. Not exactly sure if it was the way it was served or just being uncomfortable while eating, but it wasn't a great experience. 

Easily could have been tainted due to the circumstance so the next time I'm in SF I've bookmarked them for a revisit.
author: Danny W.

description:
I go here when I feel like taking a walk in fidi :) 

There are about 3 locations in fidi (that I'm aware of) and I've been to this location once! 

My favorites are spicy bacon and Unagi! It makes for a $6 lunch which is unheard of in SF. If you're feeling extra hungry, get an edamame set! It comes with 3 rice balls, edamame and pickled veggies all for ~$10!
author: Julie L.

description:
Pretty tasty for Onigilly, the shop is a bit hard to find, even when the address said market street, it's actually on 1st pass Focaccia Market & Bakery.
Ordered Matcha Lemonade (not too sweet or acidic, it's perfect) & Edamame Set included salmon (ok la), snow crab (super yummy), soboro (way too salty, don't order), pickle & edamame (like store bought flavors nothing special). I like it, but if they can go easy on the salt that it would be better.
author: HL W.

description:
Not a fan.
Food was fine, but pricey. Too much salad.

Not much else to say. Doesn't seem very filling.
author: Subrat M.

description:
When my friends at work can't decide on where we wanna eat, we just go to Onigilly, because this is One place we can all agree on any day.

Incredibly long lines shouldn't put you off. Lines are long because food is fantastic; annnd line moves pretty fast so there is not much of a wait for ordering food. Waiting to pick up your food is another story. The place is super tiny, so you need to wait outside in San Francisco's super cold sun while your onigillies are being rolled up.

Crew is pretty busy to keep the line moving, so they barely have the luxury of time to chat up with you. I don't blame them and no complaints either.

The wait is Soo worth it coz, this place hits the right spot for all kindsa tastebuds. No one i know has complained about anything served here. After trying almost all of their choices, my standard has become Edamame Set that comes with your choice of 3 onigillies with a side of edamame. I get unagi, salmon and snow crab onigillies. Yum. Perfect balance of warm rice, perfectly seasoned fish wrapped up into triangles in good quality sea weed to keep em all together as one cute family. You have a choice of onigilly or a bowl which is nothing but deconstructed sushi rolls in a bowl. Yum again. Sizable portions too, so sometimes i just get two onigillis to fill me up.

They have 3 branches in SF now and we are yet to try out other locations because the one on market street is just too convenient for us.

Herez to trying out their other locations! Cheers!
author: Sujeesha V.

description:
The short: delicious unagi onigiri

Have hunger pangs? Want something savory? This is the place to go! One onigiri is good to satisfy for a snack and having 2 or 3 is good for a meal. I came around 3:30 with no lines and the onigiri was ready pronto. They offer an option to place it in a box or wrapped up (see photo). I chose the latter as I was going to eat it immediately. And when I did, each bite of the unagi onigiri was delicious!

The strange thing about each onigiri is that the pricing is really random, and they're not the same for each onigiri. There also is no seating, but most people who come to Onigilly work in the area and there is seating elsewhere around Fidi.

Verdict: coming back to satisfy those savory hunger pangs
author: Catherine W.

description: Awesome Onigiri style to-go lunch express in downtown SF. We walked over for lunch and got some ginger soda, three vegan onigiri with side of sea salt and flavored seasoning which went well with the onigiris. Edamame on the side is served with pickled radish. I will be back! They make your food very quickly and the wait is several short minutes.
author: Karlos G.

description:
Love this place!  I grew up on onigiris and this place takes me back to my childhood.  

Favorite seafood onigiris were salmon and spicy tuna.   Salmon was fluffy and tender.  The spicy tuna had green onions in it which made it way better than the regular miso tuna.  The unagi was a really close second.  

Unfortunately, the snow crab, tarako, and spicy shrimp were kind of too sweet.  What's up with the candied meat?

I'm surprised they don't offer Spam onigiris.  

I'm also surprised they don't have a special signature soy sauce to go with the onigiris.  
 
I will be back again and again...
author: John M.

description:
Ugh, there's that name again...Onigilly. I assume it refers to the Japanese term "onigiri", a stuffed rice snack, usually shaped in a triangle, that's so common in Japan they sell them packaged in convenience stores. Now assuming a Japanese person rolls his r's into l's like in those bad propaganda World War II movies, you get this offensive variation of the term. At least it's been offensive to me since I heard it, although clearly not enough for me to not go to three of them by now. This one is in the former Prime Dip space that despite its Market Street address, is really hidden away in an alcove on 1st Street in the 455 Market building.

It's an awkward space where you turn a corner and order inside but have to wait outside for your food for the lack of space. It's frankly little more than a kiosk. The local hipsters don't seem to mind blocking the doorway and getting in the way of customers after them. I decided to order the $8.74 Edamame Set, a three-pack of onigiri with some edamame and pickles on the side. They come wrapped in nori with all kinds of Japanese-style stuffings, but I went with Soboro (ginger-honey braised ground beef), Shiitake (soy-braised shiitake mushrooms), and Unagi (broiled eel with barbecue sauce) (photo: http://bit.ly/2eYVVI4).

It was pretty good though nothing compared to what my mom could do when she was alive. It's all in the way you cup your palm, don't you know? This one looks like it comes from a rice sandwich making machine. I went for a $1.25 cup of Vegan Miso Soup as a side (photo: http://bit.ly/2f30dRI) and a Purity Organic Coconut Water to wash it all down as I sat under a blazing sun in the plaza at 50 Fremont (photo: http://bit.ly/2fw4g9N). It works more as a snack than as a full-blown lunch considering my sizable appetite but of course, if I was a skinny Japanese schoolgirl, I assume I'd be stuffed from such a meal. My people suffer so.

FOOD - 3 stars...onigiri is what it is, and it's OK for something my mom didn't make
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...gee, not much there
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...can't even remember
TOTAL - 3 stars...I refuse to roll my r's into l's for the lousy name but you can slip me an onigiri if you like
author: Ed U.

description: Oh boy. This was a true find in the financial district in San Fran! I tend to avoid chains fir lunch, esp when in a great food city like SF. But we were hungry and the pictures on the window posters looked interesting, so we took the plunge. Onigilly makes these badass little triangle sushi sandwiches, wrapped in nori. They are inexpensive and delicious. Why didn't someone think of this before? You can't really eat sushi while on the go, but these little isosceles icons are totally portable. We tried three varieties. The bbq spicy bacon was well --- how would you EXPECT bbq spicy bacon sushi to be!? It was incredible. And the snow crab and spicy tuna onigilly (onigillies??) were just as good. We had two of each for about $21 and it was one of the most unusual and tasty lunches I've had in awhile. I can think of a whole bunch of places on the east coast where Onigilly would do really well. I can't wait until they come to NJ!
author: Jeff B.

description:
Onigilly combines the speed and flavors of traditional Japanese healthy snacks with the portions of an American meal.  Choose from a salad or rice bowl topped with Japanese fillings such as teriyaki chicken and smoked eel or go for the traditional Onigiri, which is a "rice ball" filled with the same.


You have a couple of options here:  Rice Bowl (which I got), Onigilly set (3 choices of onigilly), or the Soup set (2 choices of onigilly with miso soup).  The rice bowl comes with a side of edamame which I wasn't too crazy about but it's healthy.  After looking at so many options, I went with the snow crab, spicy shrimp, and soboro.  The snow crab was surprisingly fresh and oh so yummy, by far my favorite out of the three that I tried!  The spicy shrimp had a nice kick to it and had just the right amount of spice with the rice.  It was just so flavorful!  The soboro was a delicious and filling and filled me up.
author: Danny L.

description: Stopped by here for lunch the other day and was pleasantly surprised. I ordered the rice bowl, but it came with a nice large portion of mixed greens as well. For my 3 selections, I had the salmon, unagi, and renkon (sauteed lotus root which sounded interesting). Nice portions, tangy pickles and edamame. This wasn't a typical sushi rice... I can't put my finger on how it was different but I liked this better... it was really chewy and nice texture. Also just FYI, the all the meats/veggies/fish options come in their own sauce so not like a typical sushi bowl with just raw pieces of fish. I think my bowl ~$12.00 which I thought was good value for  the food.
author: Aryn C.

description:
This is such a great concept; they do it very well, and very quickly. 

Food is different & delicious.  They have veggie, seafood, chicken & beef options. 

If you like Japanese food and/ or rice, you owe yourself a visit here.  It will be a treat!
author: Will B.

description:
One of my favorite lunch spots when I'm at work. If you're in the financial area and want a healthy lunch that's not necessarily a salad, come here! The lines can get pretty long during lunch time, so either come before noon or prepare to do a little waiting. I usually get the miso lunch set, which comes with a cup of miso soup and two onigiris of your choice. Don't be fooled by the portions, two onigiris are plenty even if they don't look like it. I've ordered the edamame set before which comes with three, and I've never been able to eat my third onigiri in one sitting. 

You have plenty of choices for filling too, and they separate it from vegetarian, meat, and fish. Pescatarian? No problem. Vegetarian? No problem. Vegan? No problem. There's literally something for everyone here which is incredibly refreshing. Flavors are awesome - the rice to filling ratio is just right, so you're not just getting a ball of carbs (protein FTW). My personal favorite is the tuna, salmon and spicy shrimp. And be sure to look out for their seasonal onigiri fillings as well (pumpkin for fall? Done deal).
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Awesome place to get some delicious food to-go. So happy a friend recommended this place--it definitely did not disappoint. The line can get long but they run the place very efficiently so it moves quite fast. And you'll need the time anyway to decide on what you want to order. They have quite the selection! You can either order individual rice balls (they range from $2.47 to $3 something) or get them in a 2 or 3 set combo. I don't actually know for sure if the combos are cheaper...but I assume they are. 

I decided to go with the Edamame Set. It comes with 3 onigiris and edamame on the side. Your final price will vary depending on which of the onigiris you choose. I went with the shrimp, the crab meat, and the pollock roe. All three of them were delicious! Surprisingly flavorful for such simple food. They include just the right amount of rice to balance out the saltiness of the filling, and the seaweed they use is yummy too. The crab meat was probably my favorite, and it's actually legit crab meat...not imitation crab. 

My food was ready within 5 minutes after I ordered. The workers here are all very friendly. Fantastic experience overall! Will definitely be coming back :)
author: Ashley Y.

description:
Get the rice balls! IMO way better than the rice bowls/salads, which are quite plain and boring. The rice bowls/salads consist of your base (rice or salad) topped with their toppings, which I just like way more in the rice ball form.

My fav toppings are:
UME* - if you love Japanese plum and love sour things, this is the one for you! I am a huge sour fan, so I loved how the warm rice, salty seaweed contrasted with the sour plum. I always add some togarashi on top so it adds a nice spicy kick to the flavor mix. Highly recommend!
UNAGI* - great flavors from their unagi. if you're usually an unagi fan, you'll love this for sure


Other toppings I've tried:
Salmon - nothing too special! I found the salmon to be quite dry and unflavorful.
Snow Crab - not a fan...I felt like I was just eating a huge california roll without the avocado.
Tarako - way too fishy for me. Some people love it, some people hate it...unfortunately I was the latter.
Chicken Teriyaki - a bit weird in a rice ball, but if you usually like chicken teriyaki, you'll probably like this!

I've also tried all their zosui rice soups, which are killer on a cold day! All the different ones (spicy bacon, salmon etc) are all really good!
author: Cynthia H.

description:
This little shop always has a long line out the door during lunch times. They have ~10 ish types of onigiri (japanese rice triangles with any filling), rice bowls, and salad bowls with the same mentioned toppings. Traditionally, the rice completely covers the filling, but here they make a sandwich out of the rice triangles and slather some filling inside. These days, they also have plastic wrapped seaweed so that the seaweed wrapping is not chewy and tough from the moisture from the rice when you finally are ready to eat it.
The fillings here have been decent, and the service has always been extremely friendly. 
However, the last few times I have had onigiri here, the rice was either undercooked or dry and not seasoned. The seaweed is there for structural support, but it gets soggy on the way back and ends up making the whole thing very chewy and hard and messy to eat. The edamame set option (3 onigiris and edamame and pickled radish on the side) surprises me that they would charge extra for this "set" that comes with a few edamame and three slices of pickled radish.

They do have good filling all made with a wide variety of ingredients. Would be a good place to come for lunch for a group of diverse tastes/dietary restrictions or a quick to-go lunch if it's not during peak hours.
author: Grace P.

description: Very tasty cute little spot. I love that they clearly mark vegan items on the menu. Got there before the line formed behind me for lunch - they were super quick and very friendly. Recommend!
author: Stacy C.

description:
The perfect no-mess lunch for those who want to eat healthy and quickly.

Onigilly combines the speed and flavors of traditional Japanese healthy snacks with the portions of an American meal.  Choose from a salad or rice bowl topped with Japanese fillings such as teriyaki chicken and smoked eel or go for the traditional Onigiri, which is a "rice ball" filled with the same.

Rice ball is in quotes because at Onigilly, they take two flat pieces of compressed rice and fill the middle with your filling of choice, making it more akin to a sandwich and packed with more of the good stuff than your traditional onigiri.  I tried the crab, spicy shrimp, and unagi (eel) onigiris.  The meats themselves tasted on the lower than average quality, but by no means did I feel sick eating it, simply that they tasted frozen, and not fresh.  But this is all to keep the price of seafood relatively low, so it's acceptable.  The onigiri are shaped like triangles with sharp edges and wrapped tightly with dried seaweed, making them easy to eat without getting your hands or face filthy.  The three onigiri filled me up and for under $12, which is quite the accomplishment in San Francisco.

Come a bit early as ordering has a short line, but you can wait for up to 15 minutes for your food to be prepared if there are a lot of orders before you.  

Onigilly is a great alternative to those wanting an asian meal on the run.
author: Nadav P.

description: vegetarian stuff is awesome. Loved the teriyaki. Cheap too
author: Qasim Z.

description:
Depending on what you get, I feel like some of them are dryer than the others, but I am a fan of the spicy shrimp one. Wish the nori seaweed was a little fresher so it would've been crispy. Either that or you should eat it quick while it's warm and crispy. The rice is molded into triangles, in which I think it if it was molded by hands it would've tasted less *(sharp corners from the mold). I don't know if it makes sense, but I've had hand made onigiris that were noticeably had nicer rices. 

And yes, can get a little messy eating these.
author: Kevin L.

description:
My boss kept raving about this place, and my boss is awesome and also has refined taste, so I kept meaning to go... Today, I literally came upon it as I was rushing back to work at 2, not having eaten all day. 

I got the edamame set, which means 3 of the "rice triangles" as I prefer to call them, edamame, and pickles. I got spicy bacon, miso tuna, and snow crab. Yum yum yum. 

I liked the bacon one best... A bit warm, so not chewy nori like the cold ones. Spicy, too.

The guys working here are totally NorCal chill. Definitely a business worth supporting! The 1st st location is much less chaotic than Embarcadero center. Nice. 

Will eat here regularly so I can try allllll the ballllls!
author: Katherine R.

description: I felt it's a place for people with peculiar taste and less picky. I didn't like it personally
author: Siva Sruthi B.

description:
Get:
Ume
Takana
Unagi
Spicy Bacon
author: Steven F.

description:
Last time I was coming here, one of my coworkers described these delicious sandwiches as anime food, or something that Ash would eat before going out to tame some Pokemon. I thought it was hilariously on point.

I have only had the onigilly here, but every single one (of the 8 I've sampled so far) has been delicious. Three of them will typically be enough for a meal, which is great because there is a combo available where you can choose three plus get edamame  as well. My personal favourite is the spicy bacon. My coworkers often get the salad, and I'll probably get that my next time and update this review!

This shop is pretty small, and hidden away if you don't know where to look. You need to look for green sign they put out front (or check my photo for what the storefront looks like!). The wait for lunch is around what you'll typically find in SF.
author: Rajeev S.

description:
I'm a fan. This cute little place is perfect for grabbing a quick, relatively healthy lunch for a decent price. The employees are very friendly as well.

I ordered the miso soup combo with salmon and shrimp onigilly. The shrimp was good with a tasty sauce, but the salmon was just salmon, rice and seaweed. Salmon is the most expensive choice so I expected a little more. Everything tasted great though, including the miso soup. 

The portions look small, but the miso soup combo was the perfect portion for me. So I would recommend ordering 2 or 3 onigilly depending on how hungry you are. 

Definitely would recommend to anyone that has a hankering for some rice and fish.
author: Chelsea N.

description: I love rice balls from my time living in Japan and so was excited to check this out. Loved it!  Had the edamame set with snow crab, hijiki, and plum. Not a low carb lunch but very yummy!
author: Lisa C.

description:
SO SO SO SO SO SO SO SO OBSESSED with this place!  It's downright delicious, and you've GOT to be crazy to not like this place.

I've been here a few too many times, and every experience is worth it!  During my first visit, I ordered to edamame set that comes with 3 onigillys (got the unagi, smoke salmon, and fresh snow crab).  YUMMMM!  SO GOOD but good but food coma'd so hard at work...

Now, I order two onigillys (usually unagi and salmon/crab), which suffices for lunch!  Such an amazing deal, so healthy, and nomming on some awesome Japanese cuisine.  I'll take that any day!!!!!!

Also, the service is reliably fast, so don't be discouraged if there's a line out the door!  Also, their employees are awesome and chat with you (especially when they recognize you haha).

Ugh, I love this place so much that it's killing me.  Side note, I just noticed I'm the Duchess of this location... that seems to say a lot about my lunch habits.  Anyways, thanks for bringing such authentic food to FiDi.  A lot of people appreciate you. :)
author: Jana L.

description:
Great lunch spot if you're downtown. Lines can get kind of long but the wait is worth it. 

Definitely get the Edamame combo which gives you three Onigilly. I recommend the unagi, spicy bacon, and spicy tuna if they have it. If you don't like the Edamame you can just opt for a 4th Onigilly!
author: Brian C.

description: Just love it! I got the edamame set with unagi, salmon and chicken teriyaki. I could write a thousand words but you just got to try it yourself!
author: Bruce B.

description: went here for the first time today bc I was wanting some Karaage only to find out they only ahve that at the Kearney location. neverless the less, I still got a snow crab onigilly and a side order of tamago. Not bad. Very tasty but kinda sucks taht you can't separate the sauce from the onigilly fillings. Snow crab was tasty though and not overpowering from the lemon aioli. tamago was the standard but not homemade. will def be back to try others.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
I think I have finally completed my visits to all the Onigilly locations in San Francisco. Just kidding, that's like impossible because they keep opening up new locations... Which is AWESOME because it's easier than ever to get my onigiri fix. I love how simple this meal is. Even though it's probably not the freshest or healthiest lunch in the world, it's by far the quickest and most sufficiently filling.

As usual, I ordered the edamame set, which comes with three onigiri, daikon, and edamame. Perfect amount of food for a reasonable price. I always get a random variety of onigiri and oftentimes I ask the cashier to choose for me. They're usually good at that, and this time was no exception. My onigiri was ordered and ready to go in no time.

I arrived around 11:30 when there was literally no line, and by the time my food was done, the line was out the door. Get here early, and come here often!
author: Stefanie C.

description: If you're craving poke but also something hot, this is the perfect blend! The rice has an unexpected subtle flavor that pairs perfectly with the seafood toppings I got. I only wish there were more extra toppings that get included, like scallions or sesame seeds. I got unagi which melted in my mouth, miso salmon, and a roe. All recommended!
author: Serena W.

description: delicious food.  i got the rice bowl which included salad, edimame, dried seaweed and pickled vegetable on top.  and vinegar dressing.  for the protein i chose the chicken teriaki, salmon, and unagi.  very tasty, short wait, and nice portion.  i topped it with some salt and chili seasoning and it was great.  would visit again.
author: Richard M.

description:
I ordered the Edamame 3-pack today for lunch and I was disappointed. A wonderful concept, but if the quality and flavor are below supermarket sushi taste, it's highly disappointing. 

Another note...the tall blond-ish young man working today 8/17/17 around 11a-1p was SO unnecessarily rude! I am a first time customer and he explained the menu slowly and sarcastically, as if I were an incompetent child. Oh, cherry on top, he rolled his eyes when I asked a few more questions. He might also be an alleged racist because I'm not white like he is. 

Oh well. 

Underwhelming overall and I don't support restaurants who treat their customers like minority trash.
author: Dennis A.

description: It met my expectations and was good! A little on the saltier side for some of the flavors, but not surprised. Great to grab & go!
author: Brian B.

description:
I love the new seasonal rice soups (I forgot the name, started with a 'z') they have for Fall/Winter. I've had the salmon rice soup with ume onigiri twice as I love this combination, especially on chilly San Francisco days. The salmon rice soup has a great salty kick without being overpowering, and it is filling to carry you through the afternoon. I finish the soup but keep the onigilly as my late-afternoon, healthy snack. I can't wait to come back again!

I stopped by a 3rd time once though half an hour before they were supposed to close. They looked closed for the day so I was a bit disappointed. Did they sell out of everything for the day so quickly? Anyway, try to go on the earlier side.
author: Maile N.

description:
Ordered two onigillies (?); miso bacon and unagi. Miso Bacon was a bit of a let down as it neither delivered on the miso or the bacon. Plus it was thin on the filling which made the whole thing dry and called out for soy sauce. 
The unagi really saved the day though. Really good stuff and there was enough of it that it didn't get lost in the rice. Will eat again. 

Overall most of them are 2-3 bucks a pop so if you're in the mood for a quick and savory snack this will definitely hit the spot.
author: Boris K.

description:
Not bad - flavors are good. I am still hungry after my 14 dollar salad though; and I wished they mixed the dressing in. 
Pretty fast to order and get our food; and everything is made fresh right there and then.
author: Anne M.

description: As far as I am concerned, this is the best lunch deal. For ~10 bucks you can have 3 tasty rice balls. They are quick and the fish is fresh and the portions are big. My fav is the miso tuna salad, but really all the options are good.
author: A K.

description: The first time I went, the rice was overcooked and stuck in my throat.  I also didn't think the flavors were the same as the one on Kearny Street (Original location).  I went several more times thinking it was a one thing let down but each time I went back, it just didn't taste as good as Kearny Street?  So odd.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Awesome vegan options that aren't ridiculously priced! I ordered the edamame set with a takana, teriyaki tofu, and a renkon. I don't know which was which but all of them were so good! For about $10 I got a yummy, filling meal. Would recommend!

Note: no indoor seating
author: Senait H.

description:
I had wanted to try Onigilly for several days, but the incredibly long lines kept putting me off.  I decided to try a different tack; I came really early in the hope of beating the wait - success!

To maximize the tasting experience, I tried pretty much one of everything from the veggie menu - even some of the exotic-sounding stuff, i.e, soy-braised shiitake mushroom sandwich, green onion sandwich, and the eggplant in red miso with sesame.

My conclusion: This place really hits the nail on the head!  It's difficult to find such a tasty variety of gluten free and vegan options at such reasonable prices anywhere!  The value proposition here is truly exceptional :-)

Tip: You only need two or three of their sushi sandwiches to satisfy even a hearty appetite
author: Crystal L.

description:
Onigilly seems to be a really popular go-to spot in San Francisco during the weekdays. Since I'm not crazy about Onigiris due to the rice to meat ratio being so hearty, I didn't prioritize visiting Onigilly for a long time. However, my buddies at Salesforce really like it so we visited this location recently.

I was pleasantly surprised to see that they offer bowls too now! I went for the bowl with half rice half salad and various toppings. I really enjoyed the Crab meat here. So yummy.

Overall- this location feels cleaner but there's zero seating so as others have mentioned, it's a quick pick up and go type place. The lunch rush is from 12-1 so go early or expect a 15 mins wait between ordering and picking up!
author: Veronica S.

description:
I love onigiri, but don't encounter them often, so I was super excited to discover this place tucked into a little spot near my office. They're open pretty late for a "lunch" place (11-4, I believe), so I stopped by a little after 3 today for a snack. The guy at the counter recommended the spicy Korean BBQ beef (or something like that) onigilly, so I got that, and I also tried a tamagoyaki. Total was just over $6 - not bad, given the location.

Both were delicious! The beef was warm, just a little sweet and a tad spicy, and reminded me a bit of a sloppy joe (in a good, nostalgic way), but wrapped in sticky rice and seaweed. The tamagoyaki was also very satisfying, and felt both healthy and indulgent.

I'd like to try some of their other flavors!
author: Liz F.

description: Great spot for a quick lunch/ take out. I've tried all Onigilly fillings and they're all are good. I've tried the bowls as well and the quality of their ingredients are superb. I could eat here everyday if I could :D
author: Layla S.

description:
Onigilly has pretty good food for value. $12 for edamame set - chicken terriyaki, unagi, and salmon (3 Onigilly). 

The portions are large so if you are pretty hungry, this will be filling. There is a hand full of edamame and 3 pieces of pickled.
author: Nina M.

description: This is surprisingly filling and the pieces are much larger than I had expected. Yes, it's a lot of rice, so it's not something I'd choose everyday, but it's a nice occasional treat. Split a set with a friend, got the salmon. It was really tasty, loved the crispy seaweed wrap and the fresh fish. I was super full after. I'll keep this on rotation.
author: Shoole S.

description: Great new spot right by my work! I'd seen this spot a few times when I go on my daily walks and decided to come here for lunch. The place is small and a bit cramped (it's strictly to go, but right around the corner there are plenty of seats for anyone). The place is clean though and the workers were very friendly. I ordered the Miso Soup Combo and got the Spicy Bacon and the Teriyaki Chicken. The food was really good! I've never had rice balls like this, but it reminded me of sushi for the most part. The soup was very good too and still warm after my walk back to work. The pricing was good with the only real gripe being I wish the combo included one more rice ball and then I know I would have been full enough! Overall, good spot and a place I can see myself coming back to soon to try out their other items on the menu!
author: James R.

description: Just yummmmm! This is becoming my go-to place for lunch! It's nutritious and healthy! Plus it's fresh!
author: Vipul S.

description:
I got the edamame set and chose three onigiri--- after contemplating for ten seconds, I just chose the three most expensive sounding ones. I got the snow crab, the unagi, and the salmon. The set came with edamame and three slices of daikon pickles. It was empty when I came so they made it really fast and after I ordered, I was out of there in a matter of one and a half minutes. 

Salmon - It's cooked salmon, not sashimi. 

Snow crab - It was kind of like a giant California roll minus the avocado.

Unagi - "It's what the Japanese call... Unagi." -Ross Gellar (honestly, this was my favorite because it was stuffed with unagi and I could see it poking out from the top when I opened the box. YUUUM! FRESHWATER EEL!

Everything was good honestly. It was a bit expensive for just three rice balls at $11.50 but I did choose the most expensive ones :( I thought the edamame was included in the set but it's actually a $0.45 charge. Next time I'll try the $2~something ones because as filling as three onigiri are for a meal, you can get hungry really fast in an hour when it all digests. There is a bottle of spicy sauce on the counter against the wall along with a bottle of sea salt? I didn't use any of that since I just took mine to go. There are no seats but I guess you can eat standing up against the wall on the counter if you wish.
author: Diana C.

description:
Financial district could use more Onigilly and a lot less Specialtys.

The staff at this particular location is very nice, polite and helpful. The food is pretty good, and priced right given the location.

Overall concept is pretty cool possibly one of the healthiest lunch options DTSF.
Downsides are - almost guaranteed to have a line at lunch, and no inside seating.
Trust.
author: Oleg H.

description:
Good triangular hand rolls. 3 is a good amount for lunch with some edamame. If anything I would say that I could deal with a little less rice and more meat/fish etc... Price is about $10-11 and that's about avg in SF. I've come here a few times already for lunch. They are very quick. 

No tables here so it's a quick pick up and go!
author: Ryan C.

description:
It's true: there is an exceptional amount of sushi restaurants in the Bay Area, but nary a place that specializes in the cheap, filling, and quick snack item that is onigiri. Solution (well, at least in the city): Onigilly! 

I've been meaning to try the location on Kearny, but there was always a line. So I was definitely excited when one opened up right across the street from my building, taking the place of that prime rib sandwich business. Upon finding out they were open for business, I rushed over to FINALLY give them a try. 


The edamame and radish option ($9-$11 depending on what kind of onigiri you order) gave me the option of choosing 3 different flavors. I went with natto, unagi, and teriyaki chicken, and out of those flavors, natto appealed to me the most. Unagi and teriyaki were very delicious in their own right, but the flavors were quite overwhelming, and for the amount of brown rice in each piece, it wasn't enough to nullify the flavors. Natto tasted a bit sweet, thick, and healthy! However, I wouldn't advise everyone to order it; natto is an acquired taste, it seems. 

For convenience and flavor, I give it a 3.5 (rounded to 4) for now...because I'm coming back to try more flavors soon!!
author: Viet N.

description:
GREAT addition to the 'hood!

While the space is super tiny and often has long lines - and BADLY needs some kind of loudspeaker to tell folks waiting outside that their order is ready - the food here is amaze-balls.

You really can't go wrong with the traditional onigilly - all of their protein accompaniments are awesome, and they mix it up with cool seasonal choices (there's a squash filling on the menu right now for winter).  However, I usually do the rice bowl to make the eating process a bit more civilized for cubicle life.  

I pretty much always get the salmon, unagi, and snow crab over rice.  The salmon is a little boring sometimes, but the other proteins are VERY flavorful, so I feel like I need to balance those out.  I'm not super crazy about the tuna - it skews bland like the salmon, plus it gets really stinky in my office.

They have zōsui on the menu right now as another winter special (a rice porridge soup) that's really good, and their salads / edamame are enjoyable.

I always feel awesome about my life after eating here :)
author: Tay H.

description:
I had been to a different location a while back but now that they've opened one right next to where I work, I'm sure it'll become one of my regular lunch spots

It's pretty good! I'll probably try every style once so here's my running list:

- unagi: delicious. I'll always include one of these
- snow crab: decent. Wouldn't necessarily reorder
- hijiki: flavors were a bit too strong for me
author: Laura D.

description: I decided to eat vegetarian for the day and it was a really good option for lunch. I had the miso soup set (which was vegan, no need to worry about any fish!) with two of their veggie rice balls, and it was delicious. It definitely satisfied my sushi craving, although a part of me missed the wasabi and soy sauce. Still, it was a great meal!
author: Trishna P.

description:
What a great spot for lunch!

I came in around 11:30AM and the place was pretty quiet. I ordered the Tarako, Soboro, with a side of chicken karaage. Everything was soo good! The Tarako was definitely my favorite, baked roe with aioli.

My boyfriend got the tuna, chicken teriyaki, and unagi. Personally, I think you can pass on the tuna and chicken, nothing really special there. But I would definitely order the unagi again.

Food is fresh and you can see them making everything right in front of you. I wish they had hot sauce or soy sauce available. They do have salt and this dry pepper mix. 

I recommend going early. As soon as we sat down with our food, there was a line forming out the door.

All in all, a really sweet spot for lunch and can be very filling for under $10. :-)
author: Angie S.

description: The person who prepared my onigillies, 2 minutes before she did so, wiped a counter top with a used towel while wearing gloves. She did not change her gloves and started making my order. Not sanitary! Hope I don't get sick.
author: George L.

description:
Sometimes you just crave some simple carbs and protein as a snack...what a perfect combo in the form of rice balls! This is a throwback to my study abroad days in Asia where you can pop into a convenience store and grab some cheap pre-made rice balls to go. 

Onigilly brings that same convenience to SF, while offering really fresh ingredients. I usually opt for the Edamame Set (3 rice balls + edamame + pickled veggies) for lunch. My favorite rice balls are the unagi (soft, flaky eel), spicy shrimp (bay shrimp with just a little kick), and salmon. This FiDi location is very quick and efficient, which is a slight improvement over the Kearny/Bush store. Although I usually come around 1PM, so I may just have beaten the lunch rush. 

The price is slightly higher than I'd like to pay for lunch (~$9-10), but you do get a decent portion of rice and meat in these rice balls.

If you're tired of grabbing the typical sandwich/salad combo for lunch, try out Onigilly!
author: Bonnie Z.

description: This is a staple go to for when you don't know what to eat but just need some daily fuel. Very prompt service.
author: K. W.

description: A great quick lunchtime meal! I highly recommend the unagi onigiri, as everyone suggests. It's the most flavourful ingredient and was delicious.
author: Karey S.

description: I love this concept and enjoyed this format in Japan. Having the wrapped rice and protein/vegetable in a nice little triangular package is fun and convenient. However, I found all three flavors I tried to be lacking something. The salmon was the most bland, but ok. The eggplant *sounded* delicious but actually turned out the worst, in my opinion . And the special bogi beef was ok - but basically afterwards, we decided hot sauce would have really helped!
author: Lisa K.

description: Love this place! It's not really cheap, but the quality of so high, and it's super healthy. The snow crab onigiri is my favorite! Two onigiri about fills me up, but it's much nicer to have three.
author: Cat M.

description:
I found out about this place because my coworker got lunch here, and smelling his onigilly made my mouth water! He has tried soboro, natto, and unagi. He said the natto was slimy and tasted like someone put snot all over his mouth. In fact, he took one bite, spit it out, and threw away the rest. He liked the other ones though!

I got the chicken zosui (rice porridge), unagi (eel), and soboro (beef), for a total of $11.40. Pretty standard prices for downtown SF! The food was fresh, warm, and flavorful. The people were polite and speedy. I think this is the perfect place for a quick lunch or on-the-go snack. 

I will definitely be back, especially for the unagi!
author: Crystal T.

description:
I have a daughter who has an egg allergy and knew some of these foods depend on mayo as a "glue" to keep them together. So I wanted the person manning the register to know that. I was concerned of cross contamination from other foods containing mayo also. The guy made multiple passes to the assemblers of my daughter's allergy. 

Both of my daughters gobbled up the Salmon Oni/Miso lunch The snow crab I loved the most. 

Big ups to the guy at the register! And the staff! Daddy day care is most great full.
author: Joe K.

description:
Great spot for a small lunch. Great for Vegetarians/Vegans.

Two Onigilly are probably good for a small lunch.

Here's what I tried:

1. Teriyaki Tofu (Sauce is good)
2. Renkon (crunchy and mild spicy)
author: Hiral P.

description:
My manager suggested this new spot that opened up near our office so I went here around 1pm on a Friday afternoon - one of the few popular spots in fidi without a line. SCORE. You're basically eating sushi in a different form imo, minus the wasabi and excessive soy sauce.  

What I ordered: 
-Takana - pickled mustard greens + sesame seeds. This was a litttlee too salty even for me (and I love my sodium). Feel like this needed another sauce / topping of some sort to come together. 
-Shiitake - mushrooms in some teriyaki type sauce. This was delicious - lots of fillings and the teriyaki wasn't too powerful. 

Pros:
+For $6, I got two rice balls - really good deal because they're pretty large and can fill you up (would recommend 3 if you're really hungry) 
+Got my order ~5 min after ordering
+Lots of vegetarian options - can't wait to try more
+They use brown rice!
+They have this interesting mix of spices you can add to your rice balls - definitely try some for some extra kick! 

Cons:
-No seating
author: Anu P.

description: 2 stars for good service. I ordered the vegan options. Eggplant, tofu and another one I forgot. I thought they were all disgusting. One reminded me of eating a pb&j and they all tasted almost identical. Pretty much turned out to be a bunch of goo drenched in sauce between some rice. Maybe outside the veggie options are better. My experience aside from the awesome customer service was really bad - I didn't finish my food, not even close.
author: Sammy S.

description:
Warning, this place is hard to find for the first time customers. 

I ordered one set of three rice balls with some pickle and beans as side. The rice ball tastes good. The rice is not too soft nor too hard. The chicken teriyaki is tastes but a little bit too salty. The unagi tastes fantastic. I also ordered a salmon, it tastes just fine. 

Another bonus about this place is you can see them making the rice ball from windows. Not a big deal, but something fun to do while waiting.
author: Wei X.

description:
Love this place after Soul Cycle. 

The lines move fast if they are present. Cheap and tasty when you need a pick-me-up or full meal. 

Spicy Bacon- This was good but not my favorite
Eel- This was my favorite. Good amount of sauce and rice.
Snow Crab- 2nd favorite only because it was plain to round out the other 2 flavor packs.

Tamago- I prefer mines a bit sweeter. I would skip this next time. 

Don't forget to get the spices on the rack to add onto the balls.
author: Carrie Y.

description:
Although I messed up with picking up my order at the wrong location, the cashier was completely understanding and graciously accommodated my order even though the line was out the door. This was done all with a smile on his face. 

This on top of consistently great food has made 5 stars totally well worth it. The amount of rice is plenty but never exceeds the flavor of the meat or filling you choose to add with it. Always so fresh too.
author: Cyril B.

description:
I usually get the miso soup + 2 onigilly set for $7.88 including tax. 

The onigilly pieces (triangle shaped) are surprisingly filling. I originally thought I would need 3 but 2 is more than enough for me. My favorite flavors are Soboro (ginger ground beef) and Spicy Shrimp. Both have a flavorful sauce combined with the protein. 

The line to order isn't usually long but it takes a long time for them to prep all of the food. It takes on average 8-10 minutes to get your food.
author: CL S.

description: Enjoyed the food here and the service! I ordered a combo - it came with wakame salad and two onigiri. I chose salmon and unagi! The salmon onigiri was a bit dry, but the unagi one was delicious. The seaweed salad was a strange color, but it still tasted good. Everything was prepared really quickly and I received my food only a few minutes after ordering. The employees were nice and asked everyone in my group how their day was going when each of us paid. The menu was easy to read and very visually appealing, although it was hard at first to figure out if the combos were actually a better price than just buying the individual rolls. I ended up getting a combo because I wanted a mix of different things, and it turned out to be just the right amount of food. Although the onigiri look small, they are pretty filling! If I came again, I would want to try some of the other rolls, but I would definitely recommend the unagi one.
author: Kathy C.

description: Heard from a coworker that Onigilly took over the Prime Dip in our building which was struggling.  Ppl don't want a surf and turf dipped sandwich for lunch to fall asleep to :)   Happy to see they had various options outside the rice balls.  Tried the salad bowl with three items:  unagi, spicy shrimp and chicken.  Liked all three, the unagi and shrimp were excellent.  Very filling and for $11 not bad for a good sized salad in downtown SF.  Asked the owner if they have been doing well and he said yes.
author: Josh L.

description: I came in with pretty high expectations thanks to all the beautiful pictures I saw on Yelp beforehand. I ordered the salmon and eel with the miso set, but I'm only going to review the salmon because that one let me down the most :( It was way too oily; with every bite, oil dripped down my hands and arm. There was a puddle in my container by the time I finished. Would not recommend the salmon at all, unless they decide to change the amount of oil they use.
author: Shannon W.

description:
The spot:  Located right next to the always crowded Focaccia, you'd miss it if not for the sign out front.

The food:  Ordered the Edamame trio (3 onigiri, a small scoop of edamame, and a small scoop of pickles).  Pretty decent.  Got the snow crab, the spicy bacon, and the Soboro and ate them in that order.  Snow crab was good.  Spicy bacon had more kick than I appreciate (but I know everyone has a different tolerance).  And the Soboro was just ok, though I'm thinking the spicy bacon killed some semblance of my taste buds.

Value:  Just under $11.  Not bad for downtown SF, but paying that price for some prepared scoops and rice anywhere else would be a little much.
author: David L.

description: A good Japanese style lunch place for you to grab a quick bite.  Arrive before 12 to avoid the line.  I like the zozui the most since I like something warm.  Most of their onigiri can get cool easily so plan your lunch seats ahead!
author: Edison T.

description: Yay finally Onigilly is close to me!!! Love their Soboro and Unagi rice balls! Price is good and affordable!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Not bad fast-ish Japanese hand rolls.  The salmon is the shredded kind, the miso was so-so but certain other items were good.
author: Peter J.

description: Just picked up an edamame set from this new location and I'm wishing I went to my normal one in the embarcadero center... I arrived well after the lunch rush and was not greeted nor even looked at when I entered the door. The two gentlemen were chatting and cleaning and I had to ask if they were still open. I placed my order for a snow crab, salmon, and spicy shrimp, but the music was so loud that I had to repeat myself several times. Once I received my order and tasted it back in the office the shrimp was chewy and EXTREMELY fishy tasting. The other two were less fishy and had better texture and flavor. Not sure if it was older shrimp because I came so late, but I will definitely not be ordering it next time.
author: Ashley R.

description: I think people who said their onigiri is good just don't know what Japanese onigiri is supposed to taste. It is kind of offensive (to me) that they name their rice balls as onigilly. I hope someone will bring real Japanese onigiri here... These onigiris are just fake.... at lease to me... No Japanese will buy these in Japan.
author: Maki N.

description: I usually get the salad with 3 onigily choices. I've tried the bacon, braised beef, seaweed, salmon, tuna, snow crab, and the unagi. All are delicious!!! I would give this place 5 stars but the amount that they give you over rice or salad is so small. I'm addicted to this place! My favorite onigily by far is the unagi, bacon, and snow crab.
author: Natalie B.

description: Quick, fresh, and affordable. Portions are substantial. It's standing-room only, so prepare to wait for your food and enjoy elsewhere. I've only tried the onigilly here, but am eager to go back for one of their bowls.
author: Brianna M.

description:
OMG -- SOOO good!  This is a great place for vegans or vegetarians as there are a lot of veggie options.

And very reasonably priced with great service!  My new favorite quick lunch in the FiDi!
author: Jane D.

description: Patience is a virtue, but it is unfortunately not a virtue that I have, meaning lunch times in SF is an absolute nightmare since I hate waiting. Onigilly is quick with relatively short wait time both to order and to get the food, making this one of my go-tos when I'm in a rush (there's no seating). It's also relatively healthy unless you're one of those people who avoid eating carbs like the devil, although portion may be a bit small if you eat a lot. Still, pricing is reasonable ($2-3/rice ball), and with such quick wait times, highly recommended for a fast lunch.
author: Michelle Y.

description: I don't really understand the hype for this place? It's just a small portion of food wrapped in seaweed and rice. Honestly anyone can make that themselves. Non the less the food was good, but for the price to ratio it doesn't seem to fit with me. I don't think I would come back. Not because of the food because it was delicious. More because of the price.
author: Pj A.

description: What an awesome find! If you haven't- get to it! Simple order set up, quick, and very happy with the yummy goods. Awesome order taker who even took the moment to explain food items to our group! Considering this is right in the mix of SF the prices really were on the lower side especially with the yummy that you get! On the list for a revisit next time in town on business!
author: Rebecca M.

description: Delicious onigiri - make sure to take 2-3 if you're hungry. Organic matcha tea/lemonade is absolutely amazing.
author: Sergey K.

description: Not too impressed. The Onigiri's from the japanese stores are way better.
author: Hitomi L.

description: Love the concept.  I never tire of sushi but sometimes you just want something simpler and not a full on roll.  Selection for the various meat, seafood, or veggie options is descent.  Cashier is really friendly and courteous.  I got there at 11:30 and apparently just missed the lunch rush so the wait for my food was pretty short.  I got the unagi, salmon, and teriyaki tofu.  Rice was a tad on the hard/dry side but maybe it was just an off batch?  Tofu and salmon were alright.  Unagi was my favorite and I'll definitely be back for that and maybe try a few other different ones.
author: Stephanie W.

description: This place was amazing! I tried the Edamame set with the bacon, crab, and mushroom rice balls and they were all great!  The bacon was spicy and flavorful, which the crab was a little more bland but still tasty.  My favorite was the mushroom as it wasn't overwhelming but still very tasty.  I will definitely go back and try their soups and salads and other flavors!
author: Meredith S.

description: delicious and affordable option near my office!  they have lots of interesting rice balls, and their ratio of rice to filling is excellent.  i will definitely be back!
author: Neda B.
